title: CanEpiRisk
text: Quantifying cancer risks associated ionizing radiation exposure central concern radiation epidemiology public health, particularly estimating lifetime risks across populations exposure scenarios. CanEpiRisk comprehensive R package designed facilitate radiation-associated lifetime risk calculations. package provides integrated framework importing exposure demographic data, transferring specified risk models—excess relative risk (ERR) excess absolute risk (EAR) computing key risk measures, including cumulative excess risk (CER) years life lost (YLL). offering unified interface evaluating risks various exposure scenarios across diverse population settings, CanEpiRisk streamlines workflow radiation risk assessment, enhances analytical reproducibility, enables transparent comparison model-based estimates.

text: Using/Specifying reference data. Using/Specifying risk models Calculating risks.

title: Using/Specifying Risk Models
code: library(CanEpiRisk)

title: Using/Specifying Risk Models
text: risk model used risk calculations CanEpiRisk package may predefined model either LSS mortality risk model object (LSS_mortality) LSS cancer incidence model object (LSS_mortality). Otherwise, user can specify risk model list object certain format.

title: Using/Specifying Risk Models
text: ERR EAR risk models cancer mortality incidence derived recent Life Span Study Japanese atomic-bomb studies available predefined objects; LSS_mortality LSS_incidence. risk model endpoint (.e., site-specific cancer incidence mortality) list object contains vector parameter estimates para, matrix variance-covariance matrix parameter estimates var function calculate risk f.

title: Using/Specifying Risk Models
text: risk model may specified list object structure LSS risk model object (LSS_mortality LSS_incidence). example, risk models derived INWORKS cohort mortality solid cancer (Richardson et al., 2015) leukaemia (Leuraud et al., 2015) can specified follows. Note uncertainty risk model parameter (ERR/Gy) specified 95% confidence interval, instead variance-covariance matrix LSS risk models objects.
code: INWORKS_mortality <- NULL INWORKS_mortality$allsolid <- NULL  INWORKS_mortality$allsolid$L <- list(      err=list(        para=c(0.47),                  # ERR/Gy=0.47 (90% CI: 0.18,0.79)          ci= c(0.1392403, 0.8521128),   #  95% CI coverted from 90%CI by Weibull approx.        f=function (beta, data, lag=10) {            beta[1] * data$dose  * (data$age - data$agex >= lag )        }        ),       ear=list(    # dummry object        para=c(4.8/10000),        ci= c(0.1068428, 12.5703871)/10000,        f=function (beta, data, lag=10) {            beta[1] * data$dose  * (data$age - data$agex >= lag )        }         )     )  INWORKS_mortality$leukaemia$L <- list(      err=list(        para=c(2.96),                         # ERR/Gy=2.96 (90% CI: 1.17, 5.21)         ci= c(0.8664, 5.6940),        f=function (beta, data, lag=2) {            beta[1] * data$dose  * (data$age - data$agex >= lag )        }        ),       ear=list(    # dummry object        para=c(2.25/10000),        ci=c(0.5064054, 4.4914628)/10000,        f=function (beta, data, lag=2) {            beta[1] * data$dose  * (data$age - data$agex >= lag )        }         )   )  INWORKS_mortality #> $allsolid #> $allsolid$L #> $allsolid$L$err #> $allsolid$L$err$para #> [1] 0.47 #>  #> $allsolid$L$err$ci #> [1] 0.1392403 0.8521128 #>  #> $allsolid$L$err$f #> function (beta, data, lag = 10)  #> { #>     beta[1] * data$dose * (data$age - data$agex >= lag) #> } #>  #>  #> $allsolid$L$ear #> $allsolid$L$ear$para #> [1] 0.00048 #>  #> $allsolid$L$ear$ci #> [1] 1.068428e-05 1.257039e-03 #>  #> $allsolid$L$ear$f #> function (beta, data, lag = 10)  #> { #>     beta[1] * data$dose * (data$age - data$agex >= lag) #> } #>  #>  #>  #>  #> $leukaemia #> $leukaemia$L #> $leukaemia$L$err #> $leukaemia$L$err$para #> [1] 2.96 #>  #> $leukaemia$L$err$ci #> [1] 0.8664 5.6940 #>  #> $leukaemia$L$err$f #> function (beta, data, lag = 2)  #> { #>     beta[1] * data$dose * (data$age - data$agex >= lag) #> } #>  #>  #> $leukaemia$L$ear #> $leukaemia$L$ear$para #> [1] 0.000225 #>  #> $leukaemia$L$ear$ci #> [1] 5.064054e-05 4.491463e-04 #>  #> $leukaemia$L$ear$f #> function (beta, data, lag = 2)  #> { #>     beta[1] * data$dose * (data$age - data$agex >= lag) #> }   # Plotting solid cancer mortality risk, male,  #          6.7(100/15)mGy at ages 30-45, followed up to age 60, LSS-L, LSS-LQ and INWORKS models  exp4 <- list( agex=30:44+0.5, doseGy=rep(0.1/15,15), sex=1 )   # Exposure scenario opt4_err <- list( maxage=90, err_wgt=1 )    # for ERR transfer opt4_ear <- list( maxage=90, err_wgt=0 )    # for EAR transfer  lss_err_L  <- Comp_Exrisk( exposure=exp4, riskmodel=LSS_mortality$allsolid$L,     option=opt4_err ) lss_err_LQ <- Comp_Exrisk( exposure=exp4, riskmodel=LSS_mortality$allsolid$LQ,    option=opt4_err ) inw_err_L  <- Comp_Exrisk( exposure=exp4, riskmodel=INWORKS_mortality$allsolid$L, option=opt4_err )  lss_ear_L  <- Comp_Exrisk( exposure=exp4, riskmodel=LSS_mortality$allsolid$L,     option=opt4_ear, per=10^4 ) lss_ear_LQ <- Comp_Exrisk( exposure=exp4, riskmodel=LSS_mortality$allsolid$LQ,    option=opt4_ear, per=10^4 ) inw_ear_L  <- Comp_Exrisk( exposure=exp4, riskmodel=INWORKS_mortality$allsolid$L, option=opt4_ear, per=10^4 )  plot( c(30,90), c(0,0.1), type="n", ylab="Excess relative rate", xlab="age (years)" ) lines( lss_err_L, lty=2 ) lines( lss_err_LQ, lty=3 ) lines( inw_err_L ) plot( c(30,90), c(0,5), type="n", ylab="Excess absolute rate (cases per 10,000 person years)", xlab="age (years)" ) lines( lss_ear_L, lty=2 ) lines( lss_ear_LQ, lty=3 ) lines( inw_ear_L )

title: Using/Specifying Reference Data
code: library(CanEpiRisk)

title: Using/Specifying Reference Data
text: Reference baseline information cancer mortality incidence rates may use predefined list object global regions cancer motality rates (Mortality) cancer incidence rates (Incidence). Otherwise, user can specify reference baseline information list object defined format.

title: Using/Specifying Reference Data
text: Mortality list object containing mortality rate reference data five global regions: Australia–New Zealand & Europe & Northern America Northern Africa & Western Asia Latin America & Caribbean Asia (excluding Western Asia) Sub-Saharan Africa regional list contains 18 site-specific cancer mortality datasets, provided data.frame objects following cancer sites: esophagus, stomach, colon, liver, pancreas, lung, breast, prostate, bladder, brainCNS, thyroid, all_leukaemia, all_cancer, allsolid-NMSC, allsolid, leukaemia, allcause, survival. region- site-specific data.frame contains three rows: age – age (years), male – age-specific mortality rate males, female – age-specific mortality rate females. age-specific mortality rates provided one-year age intervals (1 100 years) linearly interpolated corresponding 5-year interval rates. Baseline rates may plotted using plot_refdata().

title: Using/Specifying Reference Data
text: Incidence list object containing mortality rate reference data five global regions: Australia–New Zealand & Europe & Northern America Northern Africa & Western Asia Latin America & Caribbean Asia (excluding Western Asia) Sub-Saharan Africa list object region contains data.frames objects 16 site-specific cancer incidence risk models derived Life Span Study (esophagus, stomach, colon, liver, pancreas, lung, breast, prostate, bladder, brainCNS, thyroid, all_leukaemia, all_cancer, allsolid-NMSC, allsolid, leukaemia). region- site-specific data.frame contains three rows: age – age (years), male – age-specific incidence rate males, female – age-specific incidence rate females. age-specific incidence rates provided one-year age intervals (1 100 years) linearly interpolated corresponding 5-year interval rates.

title: Calculating cumulative excess risks
code: library(CanEpiRisk)

title: Calculating cumulative excess risks
text: exposure scenario, baseline data risk model appropriately provided, cumulative excess risk due (CER) exposure can calculated CER() years life lost (YLL) YLL(). population-averaged CER YLL can calculated population_LAR() population_YLL(), respectively.

title: Calculating cumulative excess risks
text: Using Predifined Risk Models ERR EAR risk models cancer mortality incidence derived recent Life Span Study Japanese atomic-bomb studies available predefined objects; LSS_mortality LSS_incidence. Using Risk Models defined user risk model endpoint (.e., site-specific cancer incidence mortality) list object contains vector parameter estimates para, matrix variance-covariance matrix parameter estimates var (vector ci confidence interval single parameter model) function calculate risk f. Following structure, user can define risk model interest use lifetime risk calculation using CanEpiRisk. following example uses risk models derived INWORKS cohort mortality solid cancer (Richardson et al., 2015) leukaemia (Leuraud et al., 2015). Note uncertainty risk model parameter (ERR/Gy) specified 95% confidence interval, instead variance-covariance matrix LSS risk models objects. CER() uses directly 95% confidence bounds computation confidence intervals risk model single parameter.
code: # Cumulative excess risk (CER) calucations  # (1) All solid cancer mortality, Region-1, female, 0.1Gy at age 15, followed up to age 100, LSS linear ERR exp1 <- list( agex=5, doseGy=0.1, sex=2 )   # exposure scenario ref1 <- list( baseline=Mortality[[1]]$allsolid,        # baseline rates              mortality=Mortality[[1]]$allcause )       # all-cause mortality mod1 <- LSS_mortality$allsolid$L                       # risk model opt1 <- list( maxage=100, err_wgt=1, n_mcsamp=10000 )  # option CER(  exposure=exp1, reference=ref1, riskmodel=mod1, option=opt1 ) * 10000 # cases per 10,000 #>      mle     mean   median  ci.2.5% ci.97.5%  #> 221.1383 227.2969 221.3405 147.4744 337.4809  # (2) Leukaemia incidence, Region-4, male, 6.7(100/15)mGy at ages 30-45, followed up to age 60, LSS LQ EAR exp2 <- list( agex=30:44+0.5, doseGy=rep(0.1/15,15), sex=1 ) ref2 <- list( baseline=Incidence[[4]]$leukaemia,       # baseline rates              mortality=Mortality[[4]]$allcause )       # all-cause mortality rates mod2 <- LSS_incidence$leukaemia$LQ                     # risk model opt2 <- list( maxage=60, err_wgt=0, n_mcsamp=10000)    # option CER(  exposure=exp2, reference=ref2, riskmodel=mod2, option=opt2 ) * 10000 # cases per 10,000 #>         mle        mean      median     ci.2.5%    ci.97.5%  #>  3.68374227  3.64270109  3.61730996 -0.04646003  7.29384756 INWORKS_mortality <- NULL INWORKS_mortality$allsolid <- NULL  INWORKS_mortality$allsolid$L <- list(      err=list(        para=c(0.47),                  # ERR/Gy=0.47 (90% CI: 0.18,0.79)          ci= c(0.1392403, 0.8521128),   #  95% CI coverted from 90%CI by Weibull approx.        f=function (beta, data, lag=10) {            beta[1] * data$dose  * (data$age - data$agex >= lag )        }        ),       ear=list(    # dummry object        para=c(4.8/10000),        ci= c(0.1068428, 12.5703871)/10000,        f=function (beta, data, lag=10) {            beta[1] * data$dose  * (data$age - data$agex >= lag )        }         )     )  INWORKS_mortality$leukaemia$L <- list(      err=list(        para=c(2.96),                         # ERR/Gy=2.96 (90% CI: 1.17, 5.21)         ci= c(0.8664, 5.6940),        f=function (beta, data, lag=2) {            beta[1] * data$dose  * (data$age - data$agex >= lag )        }        ),       ear=list(    # dummry object        para=c(2.25/10000),        ci=c(0.5064054, 4.4914628)/10000,        f=function (beta, data, lag=2) {            beta[1] * data$dose  * (data$age - data$agex >= lag )        }         )   )  INWORKS_mortality #> $allsolid #> $allsolid$L #> $allsolid$L$err #> $allsolid$L$err$para #> [1] 0.47 #>  #> $allsolid$L$err$ci #> [1] 0.1392403 0.8521128 #>  #> $allsolid$L$err$f #> function (beta, data, lag = 10)  #> { #>     beta[1] * data$dose * (data$age - data$agex >= lag) #> } #>  #>  #> $allsolid$L$ear #> $allsolid$L$ear$para #> [1] 0.00048 #>  #> $allsolid$L$ear$ci #> [1] 1.068428e-05 1.257039e-03 #>  #> $allsolid$L$ear$f #> function (beta, data, lag = 10)  #> { #>     beta[1] * data$dose * (data$age - data$agex >= lag) #> } #>  #>  #>  #>  #> $leukaemia #> $leukaemia$L #> $leukaemia$L$err #> $leukaemia$L$err$para #> [1] 2.96 #>  #> $leukaemia$L$err$ci #> [1] 0.8664 5.6940 #>  #> $leukaemia$L$err$f #> function (beta, data, lag = 2)  #> { #>     beta[1] * data$dose * (data$age - data$agex >= lag) #> } #>  #>  #> $leukaemia$L$ear #> $leukaemia$L$ear$para #> [1] 0.000225 #>  #> $leukaemia$L$ear$ci #> [1] 5.064054e-05 4.491463e-04 #>  #> $leukaemia$L$ear$f #> function (beta, data, lag = 2)  #> { #>     beta[1] * data$dose * (data$age - data$agex >= lag) #> }  # Cumulative excess risk (CER) calucations  # (1) All solid cancer mortality, Region-1, female, 0.1Gy at age 15, followed up to age 100, INWORKS linear ERR exp1 <- list( agex=5, doseGy=0.1, sex=2 )   # exposure scenario ref1 <- list( baseline=Mortality[[1]]$allsolid,        # baseline rates              mortality=Mortality[[1]]$allcause )       # all-cause mortality mod1 <- INWORKS_mortality$allsolid$L                       # risk model opt1 <- list( maxage=100, err_wgt=1, n_mcsamp=10000 )  # option CER(  exposure=exp1, reference=ref1, riskmodel=mod1, option=opt1 ) * 10000 # cases per 10,000 #>       mle      mean    median       ci1       ci2  #>  78.57894  78.57894  78.57894  23.27948 142.46409  # (2) Leukaemia incidence, Region-4, male, 6.7(100/15)mGy at ages 30-45, followed up to age 60, INWORKS EAR exp2 <- list( agex=30:44+0.5, doseGy=rep(0.1/15,15), sex=1 ) ref2 <- list( baseline=Incidence[[4]]$leukaemia,       # baseline rates              mortality=Mortality[[4]]$allcause )       # all-cause mortality rates mod2 <- INWORKS_mortality$leukaemia$L                            # risk model opt2 <- list( maxage=60, err_wgt=0, n_mcsamp=10000)    # option CER(  exposure=exp2, reference=ref2, riskmodel=mod2, option=opt2 ) * 10000 # cases per 10,000 #>      mle     mean   median      ci1      ci2  #> 4.445936 4.445936 4.445936 1.000643 8.875002

text: Getting started

title: Calculating cumulative excess risks — CER
text: Calculate cumulative excess risk due radiation exposure.

title: Calculating cumulative excess risks — CER
code: CER(exposure, reference, riskmodel, option)

title: Calculating cumulative excess risks — CER
text: exposure list object specifies exposure scenario, contains agex (single value vector age(s) exposure), doseGy (single value vector dose(s) Gy), sex (1 2 male female). reference list object specifies baseline information reference population, contains data.frame objects named baseline baseline rates target endpoint 'mortality' cause mortality rates. riskmodel list object specifies risk model, contains two list objects named err excess relative rate model ear excess absolute rate model, contains vector para model parameter estimates, matrix var variance covariance matrix, function f compute excess risk given parameter vector exposure information (e.g., dose, age exposure, sex, attained age). option list object specifies optional settings risk calculation, contains integer value maxage maximum age follow , value err_wgt weight risk transfer (1=err, 0=ear), integer value n_mcsamp number Monte Carlo samples, alpha significance level (default=0.05).

title: Calculating cumulative excess risks — CER
text: information calculated risk (vector)

title: Calculating cumulative excess risks — CER
code: # The following examples use default data provided in CanEpiRisk package  # for riskmodels (LSS_mortality and LSS_incidence) derived from Life Span Study  # and baseline mortality and incidence rates for WHO global regions (Mortality and Incidence).   # Example 1: allsolid mortality, Region-1, female, 0.1Gy at age 15, followed up to age 100, LSS linear ERR  exp1 <- list( agex=5, doseGy=0.1, sex=2 )   # exposure scenario  ref1 <- list( baseline=Mortality[[1]]$allsolid,        # baseline rates               mortality=Mortality[[1]]$allcause )       # all-cause mortality  mod1 <- LSS_mortality$allsolid$L                       # risk model  opt1 <- list( maxage=100, err_wgt=1, n_mcsamp=10000 )  # option  CER(  exposure=exp1, reference=ref1, riskmodel=mod1, option=opt1 ) * 10000 # cases per 10,000 #>      mle     mean   median  ci.2.5% ci.97.5%  #> 221.1383 227.2963 221.3405 147.4744 337.4809    # Example 2: leukaemia incidence, Region-4, male, 6.7(100/15)mGy at ages 30-45, followed up to age 60, LSS LQ EAR  exp2 <- list( agex=30:44+0.5, doseGy=rep(0.1/15,15), sex=1 )  ref2 <- list( baseline=Incidence[[4]]$leukaemia,       # baseline rates               mortality=Mortality[[4]]$allcause )       # all-cause mortality rates  mod2 <- LSS_incidence$leukaemia$LQ                     # risk model  opt2 <- list( maxage=60, err_wgt=0, n_mcsamp=10000)    # option  CER(  exposure=exp2, reference=ref2, riskmodel=mod2, option=opt2 ) * 10000 # cases per 10,000 #>         mle        mean      median     ci.2.5%    ci.97.5%  #>  3.68374227  3.64300158  3.61730996 -0.04646003  7.29646319

title: Calculating excess risks — Comp_Exrisk
code: # The following examples use default data provided in CanEpiRisk package  # for riskmodels (LSS_mortality and LSS_incidence) derived from Life Span Study  # and baseline mortality and incidence rates for WHO global regions (Mortality and Incidence).   # Example 1: allsolid mortality, Region-1, female, 0.1Gy at age 15, followed up to age 100, LSS linear ERR  exp1 <- list( agex=5, doseGy=0.1, sex=2 )   # exposure scenario  ref1 <- list( baseline=Mortality[[1]]$allsolid,        # baseline rates               mortality=Mortality[[1]]$allcause )       # all-cause mortality  mod1 <- LSS_mortality$allsolid$L                       # risk model  opt1 <- list( maxage=100, err_wgt=1, n_mcsamp=10000 )  # option  CER(  exposure=exp1, reference=ref1, riskmodel=mod1, option=opt1 ) * 10000 # cases per 10,000 #>      mle     mean   median  ci.2.5% ci.97.5%  #> 221.1383 226.8372 221.3146 147.7833 339.7893

what: Calculating years of life lost due to radiation exposure — YLL
title: Calculating years of life lost due to radiation exposure — YLL
text: Calculate years life lost due radiation exposure.

title: Calculating years of life lost due to radiation exposure — YLL
code: YLL(exposure, reference, riskmodel, option)

title: Calculating years of life lost due to radiation exposure — YLL
text: exposure list object specifies exposure scenario, contains 'agex' (single value vector age(s) exposure), 'doseGy' (single value vector dose(s) Gy), 'sex' (1 2 male female). reference list object specifies baseline information reference population, contains data.frame objects named 'baseline' baseline rates target endpoint 'mortality' cause mortality rates. riskmodel list object specifies risk model, contains two list objects named 'err' excess relative rate model 'ear' excess absolute rate model, contains vector 'para' model parameter estimates, matrix 'var' variance covariance matrix, function 'f' compute excess risk given parameter vector exposure information (e.g., dose, age exposure, sex, attained age). option list object specifies optional settings risk calculation, contains integer value 'maxage' maximum age follow , value 'err_wgt' weight risk transfer (1=err, 0=ear), integer value 'n_mcsamp' number Monte Carlo samples, alpha significance level (default=0.05).

title: Calculating years of life lost due to radiation exposure — YLL
text: information calculated risk (vector)

title: Calculating years of life lost due to radiation exposure — YLL
code: # The following examples use default data provided in CanEpiRisk package  # for riskmodels (LSS_mortality) derived from Life Span Study  # and baseline mortality rates for WHO global regions (Mortality).   # Example: allsolid mortality, Region-1, female, 0.1Gy at age 15, followed up to age 100, LSS linear ERR  exp1 <- list( agex=15, doseGy=0.1, sex=2 )   # exposure scenario  ref1 <- list( baseline=Mortality[[1]]$allsolid,     # baseline rates               mortality=Mortality[[1]]$allcause )    # all-cause mortality  mod1 <- LSS_mortality$allsolid$L                    # risk model  opt1 <- list( maxage=100, err_wgt=1, n_mcsamp=10000 )  YLL(  exposure=exp1, reference=ref1, riskmodel=mod1, option=opt1 )   # YLL #>       mle      mean    median   ci.2.5%  ci.97.5%  #> 0.2408580 0.2435779 0.2416988 0.1884468 0.3112557

title: Plotting age distributions — plot_agedist
text: agedist list object contains information region-, sex- age-specific distribution (default "agedist_rgn" object CanEpiRisk) rgn_labs vector character strings specifies labels region names shown plot. region single value vector specifies gloval region(s) (default=1:5; 1="Aus-NZ Europe Northern America", 2="Northern Africa - Western Asia", 3="Latin America Caribbean", 4="Asia excl. Western Asia", 5="Sub-Saharan Africa")

title: Plotting reference data — plot_refdata
text: plot_refdata Plots reference data cancer incidence mortality rates five global regions.

title: Plotting reference data — plot_refdata
code: plot_refdata(   dat,   outcome,   title = "",   ymax = NULL,   leg_pos = "none",   PER = 1e+05,   x_lab = "age (years)",   y_lab = "cases per 100,000 PY",   lsz = 9 )

title: Plotting reference data — plot_refdata
text: dat Mortality Incidence, contains age- sex-specific cancer incidence mortality rates cancer site region. outcome character string specifies cancer site rates plotted. title character string  specifies title plot. ymax value specifies maximum value y-axis. leg_pos vector specifies legend x-y position ((1,1) top-right; default="none" -legend). PER integer value rate denominator (default=10^5) x_lab x-axis label (default="age (years)") y_lab y-axis label (default="cases per 100,000 PY") lsz legend size (default=9)

title: Plotting reference data — plot_refdata
text: ggplot object

title: Plotting reference data — plot_refdata
text: parameter outcome can chosen one following character strings Mortality Incidence: "esophagus", "stomach", "colon", "liver", "pancreas", "lung", "breast", "prostate", "bladder" "brainCNS", "thyroid", "all_leukaemia", "all_cancer", "allsolid-NMSC", "allsolid", "leukaemia" (leukaemia excluding CLL). MOrtality, "allcause" "survival" can additionally chosen.

title: Plotting reference data — plot_refdata
code: # The following examples use default data provided in CanEpiRisk package  # for riskmodels (LSS_mortality and LSS_incidence) derived from Life Span Study  # and baseline mortality and incidence rates for WHO global regions (Mortality and Incidence)   # Example 1: All solid cancer mortality rates  plot_refdata( dat=Mortality, outcome="allsolid", title="All solid cancers mortality", leg_pos=c(0.27,0.95), y_lab="deaths per 100,000 PY" )    # Example 2: Leukaemia incidence rates  plot_refdata( dat=Incidence, outcome="leukaemia", title="Leukaemia incidence (excluding CLL)", leg_pos=c(0.27,0.95), y_lab="cases per 100,000 PY" )

title: Plotting risk models — plot_riskmodel
text: plot_riskmodel() plots excess relative absolute rates cancer incidence mortality rates based risk models derived Life Span Study given dose. scenario currently fixed ages exposure 10, 30 50 years. Age specific risks plotted ERR EAR separately male female.

title: Plotting risk models — plot_riskmodel
code: plot_riskmodel(   rm,   doseGy = 0.1,   maxage = 100,   ymax = c(1.5, 30),   leg_pos = "none",   EAR_PER = 10^4,   add = c(0, 0),   sex = "both",   x_lab = "age (years)",   y_lab = "excess rate",   title = "" )

title: Plotting risk models — plot_riskmodel
text: rm list object contains risk model information specified format described Details. doseGy value specifies radiation dose Gy Sv (default=0.1). maxage maximum age years (default=100) ymax value specifies maximum value y-axis. leg_pos vector specifies legend x-y position ((1,1) top-right; default="none" -legend). EAR_PER integer value excess absolute rate denominator (default=10^4). add vector values added female's ERR EAR values (avoid completely overlapping sex-specific values risk modified sex). sex character string specifies whether plot contains "" sexes, "male" "female" . x_lab x-axis label (default="age (years)" ). y_lab y-axis label (default="excess rate"). title character string specifies title plot (default="", .e., title).

title: Plotting risk models — plot_riskmodel
text: ggplot object

title: Plotting risk models — plot_riskmodel
text: risk model can specified list object provided CanEpiRisk package; example LSS_mortality$allsolid$L  LSS solid cancer mortality linear model, LSS_incidence$allsolid$LQ LSS solid cancer incidence linear-quadratic model, LSS_mortality$leukaemia$LQ LSS leukaemia mortality linear-quadratic model, LSS_incidence$thyroid$L LSS thyroid cancer incidence linear model.

title: Plotting risk models — plot_riskmodel
code: # The following examples use default data provided in CanEpiRisk package  # for riskmodels (LSS_mortality and LSS_incidence) derived from Life Span Study  # and baseline mortality and incidence rates for WHO global regions (Mortality and Incidence)   # Example 1: LSS all solid cancer mortality risk model  plot_riskmodel( rm=LSS_mortality$allsolid$L, title="LSS all solid cancer mortality, Linear",  leg_pos=c(0.4, 0.95) )    # Example 2: LSS Leukaemia incidence risk model  plot_riskmodel( rm=LSS_incidence$leukaemia$LQ, title="LSS leukaemia incidence", ymax=c(1.5, .3), add=c(0.01,0) ) #> Warning: Removed 6 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_line()`).
